page.title: 19Language in Low Lorton
page.content: Local accents, place names and many common words betray the influence of early settlers, especially Norse, on Cumbria, including the Low Lorton block. Vowel sounds are distinctive, harder: the long a as in face becomes fi_as; the long o as in home becomes hiam or yam; ow becomes oo as in hoo noo then; ou as bought/brought becomes bowt/browt. Go, going gone_ga, gahn, gian: ah's gahn yam. Fower rood ends_cross roads. Yan once: when yan's deun what yan can, what mair can yan deea. Lal_little, lal crack_ short chat, lal'un child: hoo's t'lal'un? A div'nt ken_ I don't know. Fell_hill/mountain. Beck_stream. Force_waterfall. How_small hill/mound. Lonning_lane. Yows_ewes. Tips_rams. Mowdies_moles. Heaf_the pasture of a fell sheep. Aye of course means yes, and is often used during conversation.
